Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Situation2: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Story: I stared at my phone, scrolling through the online store, the Nintendo console sitting in my cart. My stepson had been talking about it for weeks, and I’d promised him I’d get it if I could. But the price tag made my stomach twist. I knew how much it would mean to him, but I also knew our budget was tight. As I mulled it over, my phone buzzed with a message from my girlfriend: “Hey, we finally have a few free nights! When can we have our date?” She’d been patient, waiting for us to have time together, and I missed her. I wanted to make her feel special, to show her she was a priority. But if I bought the Nintendo, I’d have to cut back on everything else this week—including a nice night out. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of my promise to my stepson pressing against the hope in my girlfriend’s text. My mind raced, trying to figure out how to be both the reliable step-parent and the attentive boyfriend, knowing I couldn’t fully be both at once.
